advantage.name: Age
advantage.description: Starting age is one year older than normal for each level of this disadvantage. Standard starting age is 16. Maximum starting age is 30. This disadvantage allows more skills and other advantages to be purchased. A starting age above 30 does not grant any further points.

advantage.name: Branded criminal
advantage.description: You have been marked as a criminal. -2 point disadvantage for petty theft or something similar, -5 for something major (maybe dishonour in a society which highly values honour) which will cause major social problems. The brand is obvious for all to see. Note that such a person is not considered an outlaw, and to have repaid their debt to society. However, as always, people will be prejudiced against the character.

advantage.name: Black sheep
advantage.description: The character is the black sheep of the family, and can expect no support from them in times of need. Indeed, they may actively try to cause problems for him, or others who dislike the family may seem him as a way of getting even, without invoking a blood feud.

advantage.name: Dark secret
advantage.description: You have a secret in your past which is best left hidden. If someone were to find it out, or to make it public, your life could become quite complicated. This is a -2 disadvantage if the secret would be annoying if let out, or -5 if it would be a serious risk to your health (you were a member of some particularly reviled cult for instance).

advantage.name: Favours
advantage.description: You owe favours to a person, who will call them in at some point. Repaying the favours should not be a great hardship, but ignoring them will gain you a bad reputation (and possibly an enemy).

advantage.name: Orphan
advantage.description: The character is an orphan, with no parents or immediate family to stand up for you.

advantage.name: Pawn of darkness
advantage.description: Either from birth, or because of some event in your youth, your life is plagued by the interventions of dark powers, be they demons, fey or gods. Alternatively, it may have been prophesied that such will come about later in your life.

advantage.name: Social class (Outlaw)
advantage.description: An outlaw has been cast out of society for some crime. It is illegal to knowingly give aid to an outlaw, or to seek revenge for their death. This often makes the life of an outlaw hard, for they are fair game for anyone with a grudge to settle.

advantage.name: Social class (Slave)
advantage.description: Slaves have few rights, but they are not just property. Laws exist which protect them from the worst of physical abuse, and in most cases, it doesn't make economic sense to damage a slave, since they can be expensive, and often useful.

advantage.name: Social class (Serf)
advantage.description: With more freedom than a slace, serfs consider themselves well up the social ladder compared to the former. The reality isn't quite as good though. Serfs don't have much economical safety, are restricted in their movements by their lord, and are often indebted to many weeks of work on their lord's land.

description.para: A freeman is the norm for player characters, since they have the most freedom of anyone in society. They can come and go as they please, and they have few obligations, but also their lord has few obligations to them either. Freemen are allowed to carry weapons, though often they are restricted from using knightly weapons.
Player characters who have a social class less than this can be difficult to play, since they will need permissions from their lord or master before doing anything.
A guilded character is a member of a guild, and as such is allowed to practise their profession. The types of professions which require guild membership will vary from campaign to campaign.

A guild member will have certain benefits beyond simply being allowed to practise a specialist craft (and earn money from it). They may have access to tools and supplies, and be able to lodge at guild houses either for free, or at a discount. Such guild members are often respected within the community at large as well, and have the full force of their guild to back them up if anyone starts causing trouble for them.
A priest is an official member of an organised religion, with knowledge of religious traditions, social standing and at least some resources of their church.

A landless noble, often a knight, has many benefits above and beyond the common folk, even freemen. Being a noble, especially one without land, is no guarantee of wealth however, and many such nobles are poor, living by selling their sword.
A knight may carry knightly weapons, and wear knightly armour. Their dependents may also be armed as such, in order to help defend their noble lord. A knight may also own a warhorse.

A knight can expect aid from other nobles, and respect from his lessers, but is expected to live by a code of honour, which at least requires him to protect those of lesser station from outlaws and wild beasts.

A landowning noble, like their landless brethren, have a number of responsibilities and benefits, and can be considered to be the same in all regards except that they own a manor, and have people in fief to them.
A manor does not guarantee wealth, for often everything that is earnt, is spent on upkeep, taxes and presenting a face of respectability to other nobles.
Similar to a landowning noble, however, several manors are owned by one of this social class, and other nobles will answer to him. Again, wealth is not guaranteed.

A Bard is both entertainer and loremaster, respected for their knowledge of lore and law, and their skills at the spinning of tales and song. Bards can expect hospitality wherever they travel, and though they can legally expect less than a travelling knight may get, they are truly welcomed, for often they are the only source of news beyond the borders of the local village.
The reputation of a character can greatly affect how others react to him. They can be both good and bad, with good reputations having a positive cost, and bad ones a negative cost.

A reputation should be specified at a level (minor - famous), and a region it covers. A village wizard might be famous in their home village, but unheard of in the next country. Regions are as per the area lore skill.
Each level of reputation has a difficulty associated with it, and this is the target number for an area lore roll to have heard of the reputation.

targetlist.entry: Just for completness. The target number given is that needed to know of someone who has no particular reputation. However, despite what this table says, a person will know of everyone in their home village or street.
A not particularly well known reputation. Maybe the wife of an innkeeper, or son of a famous swordsman. A good fraction of people will be aware of them, but they will be unheard of outside the area.
A small reputation. A reputable craftsman. Most people in the area will have heard of the person, but very few outside the area will have.
Moderately famous, probably due to some particular event that the person was at the centre of. Practically everyone will have heard of the person.
Very famous. Everyone knows the person and is aware of their exploits, and the news has travelled wide as well, and a good number of people outside the area will be aware of them.

description.para: The character is comfortably well off, and has about a 1 pound to spend each year from various sources. When the character begins play, they have a years worth of money available for spending.
The character is quite rich, and has about 5 pounds to spend each year from various sources. When the character begins play, they have a years worth of money available for spending.
The character is very rich, and has about 20 pounds to spend each year from various sources. When the character begins play, they have a years worth of money available for spending.
